title: 110_s1685
content: The "Fairness in Drug Sentencing Act of 2007" reduces sentencing disparities for powder and crack cocaine by increasing the threshold amounts for mandatory minimum sentences. The Act amends the Controlled Substances Act and the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act to raise the threshold amounts for possession of cocaine. SEC. 3 amends the Controlled Substances Act by changing the penalty for possession of crack cocaine. SEC. 4 increases emphasis on certain aggravating factors related to the seriousness of the offense. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses involving trafficking of controlled substances to include tiered enhancements for the use of dangerous weapons or violence. This may involve increasing existing enhancements for weapon possession, adding enhancements for weapon use or violence, and any other necessary enhancements. Additionally, there will be increased emphasis on certain factors related to the culpability of the offender. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses involving trafficking of controlled substances to consider enhancements for aggravating factors associated with the offense, such as patterns of criminal conduct or livelihood involvement. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses involving trafficking of controlled substances to consider enhancements for aggravating factors such as maintaining an establishment for distribution, involving minors or pregnant individuals, location of manufacturing or distribution, and bribery of law enforcement. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses involving trafficking of controlled substances to consider enhancements for aggravating factors such as maintaining an establishment for distribution, involving minors or pregnant individuals, location of manufacturing or distribution, and bribery of law enforcement. Factors to be considered include the defendant's involvement in importation, prior felony convictions, and any other relevant factors deemed necessary. Adjustments may be made for mitigating factors like minimal knowledge of the illegal enterprise or receiving little or no benefit. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for drug trafficking offenses, considering enhancements for factors like maintaining a distribution establishment, involving minors or pregnant individuals, location of manufacturing or distribution, and bribery of law enforcement. Mitigating factors such as minimal knowledge of the illegal enterprise or receiving little or no benefit will also be taken into account. The United States Sentencing Commission must update sentencing guidelines for drug trafficking offenses promptly, within 90 days of this Act's enactment, following the procedure outlined in the Sentencing Act of 1987.
